questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
An organization has a Microsoft 365 subscription. You plan to implement multi-factor authentication.
For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

comments.content:
Basic MFA is free

 Basic multi-factor authentication features are available to Microsoft 365 and Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) users and global administrators for no extra cost. If you want to upgrade the features for your admins or extend multi-factor authentication to the rest of your users with more authentication methods and greater control, you can purchase Azure AD Multi-Factor Authentication in several ways.

Love most of your responses, syu31svc, but I don't think you're correct on this one.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/authentication/concept-mfa-licensing

MFA does not come at no cost with every type of licensing available; there are definite "upgrade" licenses which open up the feature for standard users.

(Besides that, completely agree with your sentiment about paying extra for MFA. It's absurd Microsoft doesn't include this as a free capability for every single account created no matter what licensing it has assigned. Do you want to actually promote security or not?)

discussion.content:
https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/topic/set-up-your-microsoft-365-sign-in-for-multi-factor-authentication-ace1d096-61e5-449b-a875-58eb3d74de14

Yes No Yes is correct; why would anyone want to pay extra just to enable MFA?
I think is because it says additional license instead of "upgrade" and existing one?

Next, create a conditional access policy to require multifactor authentication for members of the MFAUsers group.

In a new tab of your browser, go to https://portal.azure.com.
Select Azure Active Directory > Security > Conditional Access.
In the Conditional access – Policies pane, select New policy.

Cond Access policies is only available for Azure ADP1 licensed tenants

discussion.content: The correct choice is B, focusing on applications that manage sensitive information remaining in a hybrid environment. This decision isn't primarily because these applications can't be protected in the cloud—modern security measures like Azure Information Protection provide robust options. Rather, regulations and specific security requirements sometimes dictate that such sensitive applications stay partially on-premises, adding an extra layer of control and compliance that certain organizations might need.

Selected Answer: D
Applications that don’t contain sensitive data are good candidates for the cloud; those that do may be a better fit for a hybrid cloud. However, legacy apps - Older versions of some applications that have been around for a long time cannot be moved to the cloud without first carrying out several upgrades. Also, many organizations customized their applications to fit their needs, and they might find it challenging to find a cloud solution suitable for them. Legacy applications need extra care. I'm going with D.

Why does everyone seem to think that legacy applications can't be hosted on a VM. Let's be real here, those same legacy apps are probably on an ESXi host anyways. There's no specific details on what the apps are so we can't assume that none are able to migrate. 

I also don't understand why everyone thinks that sensitive information cannot be protected in Azure. There are tons of ways to protect it. On-premise can be a lot more insecure than cloud. It all depends on how you manage your infrastructure.

The only option that is decent is hardware tokens. There are applications that require hardware tokens for licensing as well not just authentication. Some of those apps don't support usb passthrough. Like someone else mentioned Autocad is a perfect example. Don't get tunnel vision on an answer. Think outside of the box because D and B are not the correct answer that's for sure

its correct

Selected Answer: B
Because the data is sensitive it will remain hybrid.

I would Pick B because it is the most compelling reason for an application to remain On Premises.

The accuracy of the underlined segment "All applications will remain in a hybrid environment after migrating to Microsoft Azure" depends on the specific details of the migration plan and the applications involved. Therefore, the correct answer is B, C, or D, depending on the circumstances.

Option B: Applications that manage sensitive information may not be suitable for a hybrid environment due to compliance or security concerns.

Option C: Applications that require a USB-token device may not be suitable for a hybrid environment if the device cannot be easily integrated with the cloud infrastructure.

Option D: All legacy applications may not be suitable for a hybrid environment due to compatibility or performance issues.

Therefore, the underlined segment cannot be assumed accurate without further information about the applications and the migration plan.

comments.content:
If only one option could be chosen, the most compelling reason would be Option B: Applications that manage sensitive information.

Sensitive information such as personally identifiable information (PII), financial data, and healthcare information may be subject to regulatory requirements that mandate strict security and privacy controls. Migrating these applications to a hybrid environment may introduce new security risks and compliance challenges. Therefore, it may be more appropriate to keep these applications in an on-premises environment or move them to a fully cloud-based solution that meets the necessary compliance standards.

While options C and D are also valid concerns, they may not be as critical as ensuring the security and compliance of sensitive information. Therefore, Option B is the most compelling reason to consider when deciding whether to keep applications in a hybrid environment after migrating to Microsoft Azure.

questions.question_text:
You need to consider the underlined segment to establish whether it is accurate.
All applications will remain in a hybrid environment after migrating to Microsoft Azure.
Select `No adjustment required` if the underlined segment is accurate. If the underlined segment is inaccurate, select the accurate option.

Your company has a Microsoft Office 365 subscription.
As an administrator for this subscription, you have been tasked with recommending a solution that prohibits users from copying corporate information from managed applications installed on unmanaged devices.
Which of the following should you recommend?

discussion.content: Microsoft Intune is a cloud-based service that focuses on mobile device management (MDM) and mobile application management (MAM). You control how your organization’s devices are used, including mobile phones, tablets, and laptops. You can also configure specific policies to control applications. For example, you can prevent emails from being sent to people outside your organization. Intune also allows people in your organization to use their personal devices for school or work. On personal devices, Intune helps make sure your organization data stays protected, and can isolate organization data from personal data.
"unmanaged devices" means NO Intune agent on those.

Selected Answer: B
Because of MDM ad MAM

Selected Answer: B
For sure it is B

B- Is the correct one. 
With Intune, you can protect data on managed devices (enrolled in Intune) and protect data on unmanaged devices (not enrolled in Intune). Intune can isolate organization data from personal data. The idea is to protect your company information by controlling the way users access and share information.
Protect data on any device
With Intune, you can protect data on managed devices (enrolled in Intune) and protect data on unmanaged devices (not enrolled in Intune). Intune can isolate organization data from personal data. The idea is to protect your company information by controlling the way users access and share information.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/what-is-intune

In Intune, you manage devices using an approach that's right for you. For organization-owned devices, you may want full control over the devices, including settings, features, and security.
Mobile application management (MAM) in Intune is designed to protect organization data at the application level, including custom apps and store apps. App management can be used on organization-owned devices and personal devices.
MS Intune allows you to control access to MS Office 365 from unmanged devices
"unmanaged devices" so answer is Intune; B

questions.question_text:
A company is planning to use Microsoft 365 Defender.
The company needs to protect Windows 10 client computers from malicious viruses. The company also needs to identify unauthorized cloud apps that are used by end users.
You need to identify the Microsoft 365 Defender solutions that meet the requirements.
Which two solutions should you choose? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
Tip:
Microsoft Defender for Endpoint - protect Windows 10 client computers from malicious viruses
Microsoft Cloud App Security - identify unauthorized cloud apps that are used by end users.

Microsoft Cloud App Security >> Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-cloud-apps/what-is-defender-for-cloud-apps

Selected Answer: BD
BD - Correct
Seems correct to me
